choices.text: It is a viral infection commonly seen in infants and toddlers
It begins at the gingival margins and spreads to the interdental papillae
It is caused by fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincentii and presents with necrotic slough over gingivae
Treatment primarily involves surgical debridement under general anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Vincent infection (Acute Necrotizing Ulcerative Gingivitis)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is caused by fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincentii and presents with necrotic slough over gingivae

 

Vincent infection, also called Acute Necrotizing Ulcerative Gingivitis (ANUG), is a bacterial infection affecting young adults and middle-aged persons, caused by a fusiform bacillus and a spirochaete (Borrelia vincentii). It is related to Vincent’s angina when tonsils are involved.

 

Key clinical features:

 

  • Starts at the interdental papillae, then spreads to free gingival margins
  • Necrotic slough forms on the gingivae, which appear red and edematous
  • May be associated with ulcers and necrotic membranes on tonsils (Vincent’s angina)
  • Diagnosis: Smear from the lesion
  • Treatment:
    • Systemic antibiotics (Penicillin/Erythromycin + Metronidazole)
    • Mouthwashes (e.g., sodium bicarbonate)
    • Good oral hygiene

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a viral infection commonly seen in infants and toddlers: Incorrect. It is not viral, and affects young and middle-aged adults, not infants or toddlers.

 

Option B. It begins at the gingival margins and spreads to the interdental papillae: Incorrect. It starts at the interdental papillae and spreads to gingival margins, not the other way around.

 

Option D. Treatment primarily involves surgical debridement under general anesthesia: Incorrect. Surgical debridement is not the primary treatment. It is managed medically with antibiotics, mouthwashes, and oral hygiene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vincent infection is a bacterial gingival disease caused by fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincentii, beginning at interdental papillae with necrotic slough, treated with antibiotics and mouthwashes.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 217

choices.text: Mucocele
Branchial cleft cyst
Ranula
Dermoid cyst

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents with a painless, slowly growing swelling in the floor of her mouth. On examination, a soft, cystic, translucent lesion is seen to the side of the lingual frenulum, causing upward displacement of the tongue. There is no associated fever or tenderness. Ultrasound confirms a cystic lesion arising from the sublingual gland without extension into the neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ranula

 

Fits all features: floor of mouth, sublingual origin, translucent cyst, pushing tongue upward

 

 

A ranula is a mucous retention cyst that arises due to obstruction of the ducts of the sublingual salivary gland. It typically presents as:

 

  • A translucent, soft, cystic swelling
  • Located in the floor of the mouth, usually lateral to the lingual frenulum
  • Can cause elevation of the tongue
  • Plunging ranula refers to a ranula that extends into the neck spaces
  • Treatment:
    • Small ranula: Surgical excision
    • Large ranula: Marsupialization (incision and suturing of cyst margins to the oral mucosa)
    • Complete excision may be difficult due to thin walls and tissue plane involvement

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mucocele: Also a salivary gland cyst but typically occurs on the lower lip, not the floor of the mouth

 

 

Option B. Branchial cleft cyst: Occurs in the lateral neck, not the floor of the mouth

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: May occur in the midline of the floor of mouth but is usually non-translucent, doughy, and does not arise from sublingual glands

 

 

A sublingual dermoid typically presents as a white mass in the floor of the mouth, located either in the midline or laterally, and lies above the mylohyoid muscle. Unlike a ranula, which appears translucent, a sublingual dermoid has a white, opaque appearance that often shines through the mucosa.

 

In contrast, a submental dermoid develops below the mylohyoid muscle and presents as an external swelling in the submental region, just behind the chin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ranula is a translucent cystic lesion of the floor of the mouth arising from the sublingual gland due to ductal obstruction, treated by excision or marsupialization.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 223–224

choices.text: Mumps is diagnosed by imaging and is treated with intravenous antivirals
Parotid swelling due to mumps usually resolves in 1 week with supportive care
Orchitis is the most common complication in females and often results in infertility
Mumps immunoglobulin is highly effective for post-exposure prophylaxis

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of low-grade fever, malaise, and pain in front of the right ear. On examination, there is a soft, tender swelling of the right parotid region. The swelling is warm and causes difficulty chewing. The patient has not received the MMR vaccine. He denies any discharge from the ear or dental issues. Serum amylase is elevated. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid swelling due to mumps usually resolves in 1 week with supportive care

 

Parotid swelling in mumps usually resolves within a week with supportive treatment alone.

 

The patient presents with classic signs of mumps (viral parotitis) caused by paramyxovirus, typically seen in children and adolescents. Mumps is transmitted by droplet infection and has an incubation period of 7–23 days. Key points include:

 

  • Parotid gland swelling, unilateral or bilateral, with fever, malaise, and muscular pain
  • Diagnosis is clinical, supported by elevated serum and urinary amylase
  • IgM antibodies are detectable by day 5 of illness
  • Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment: hydration, rest, analgesics, and cold/hot compresses
  • Parotid swelling typically resolves in ~1 week
  • Complications include:
    • Orchitis (painful, tender testis) – mostly in males
    • Oophoritis, pancreatitis, aseptic meningitis, sensorineural hearing loss
  • MMR vaccine is effective for prevention
  • Mumps immunoglobulin is not effective for treatment or prophylaxis

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mumps is diagnosed by imaging and is treated with intravenous antivirals: Incorrect. Imaging is not routinely required, and antivirals are not effective; treatment is supportive.

 

Option C. Orchitis is the most common complication in females and often results in infertility: Incorrect. Orchitis occurs in males, not females. Female infertility is extremely rare.

 

Option D. Mumps immunoglobulin is highly effective for post-exposure prophylaxis: Incorrect. Mumps immunoglobulin is not useful as either post-exposure prophylaxis or treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mumps parotitis is a self-limiting viral illness treated with supportive care, and the swelling typically resolves in about one week.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 231

choices.text: Oral lichen planus
Oral submucous fibrosis
Vincent angina
Erythroplakia

questions.text: A 32-year-old male from South Asia presents with complaints of progressive difficulty opening his mouth and burning sensation in the oral cavity, especially while eating spicy foods. He reports a history of chewing betel nut for several years. Examination shows blanching of buccal mucosa, palpable fibrous bands over the soft palate and pillars, and reduced tongue protrusion. He is unable to insert even one finger into his mouth. Dental hygiene appears poor with multiple carious teeth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral submucous fibrosis

 

Fits the full clinical picture: betel nut history, trismus, burning with spices, fibrotic bands, restricted tongue movement, and poor oral hygiene.

 

This patient presents with classic clinical features of Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSF):

 

  • Age group: Typically seen in 20–40 years
  • Etiology: Strong association with areca nut (betel nut) chewing
  • Symptoms:
    • Burning sensation on eating spicy food
    • Intolerance to chillies
    • Trismus (difficulty opening the mouth)
    • Restricted tongue protrusion
    • Poor oral hygiene due to limited access for cleaning
  • Findings:
    • Blanching of mucosa over soft palate, pillars, and buccal mucosa
    • Palpable fibrotic bands
    • In later stages, fibrosis may involve muscles, worsening mobility restrictions

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Oral lichen planus: Typically presents with white lacy lesions (Wickham’s striae) on buccal mucosa, often associated with mild burning, but does not cause trismus or fibrotic bands.

 

Option C. Vincent angina: An acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, presents with painful ulcers, fetid breath, fever, and gingival necrosis – not trismus or fibrosis.

 

Option D. Erythroplakia: Presents as red velvety patches, often asymptomatic and premalignant, but does not involve trismus, fibrosis, or burning with spices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral submucous fibrosis presents with progressive trismus, intolerance to spicy foods, burning mouth sensation, and fibrotic bands due to areca nut use.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 220–221

choices.text: Retromolar trigone
Pterygomandibular raphe
Anterior pillar of tonsil
Circumvallate papillae

questions.text: Which of the following structures marks the posterior boundary of the oral cavity proper?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior pillar of tonsil

 

The oral cavity extends from the lips to the oropharyngeal isthmus, which is anatomically marked by the anterior pillar of the tonsils. This is the posterior boundary of the oral cavity proper.

 

Anterior pillar of tonsil is the transition point from the oral cavity to the oropharynx and is considered the posterior boundary of the oral cavity.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Retromolar trigone: This is part of the oral cavity but lies anterior to the ascending ramus of the mandible. It is not the posterior boundary.

 

 

Option B. Pterygomandibular raphe: This is a fibrous band extending from the pterygoid hamulus to the mandible; it marks the posterior extent of the buccal mucosa but not the oral cavity proper.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate papillae: These mark the boundary between the oral tongue (anterior 2/3) and pharyngeal tongue (posterior 1/3) but do not represent the posterior limit of the oral cavity as a whole.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oral cavity extends posteriorly up to the anterior pillar of the tonsils, marking its boundary with the oropharynx.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 216

choices.text: Oral lichen planus
Candidal glossitis
Median rhomboid glossitis
Geographical tongue (migratory glossitis)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with concern about patchy areas on her tongue noticed during routine oral hygiene. She denies any pain, burning, or changes in taste. On examination, the dorsum of the tongue shows multiple erythematous patches devoid of papillae, each surrounded by irregular white keratotic borders. She mentions that the shape and location of these lesions have been changing over the past few weeks. There is no history of systemic illness or medication use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Geographical tongue (migratory glossitis)

 

Geographical tongue, also called migratory glossitis, presents as:

 

  • Erythematous patches on the dorsum of the tongue
  • These areas are devoid of papillae
  • Surrounded by irregular white keratotic borders
  • Lesions change shape and position over time
  • Typically asymptomatic and requires no treatment

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Oral lichen planus: Presents as white lacy lesions (Wickham’s striae), usually on buccal mucosa, and often symptomatic.

 

Option B. Candidal glossitis: Often presents as diffuse erythema or white patches that can be scraped off, typically associated with burning or pain.

 

Option C. Median rhomboid glossitis: Presents as a single red depapillated patch in the midline anterior to foramen caecum, not migratory or surrounded by white borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Geographical tongue presents as asymptomatic, migratory erythematous patches on the tongue with white keratotic borders, and does not require treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 220

choices.text: It is a bluish, soft cystic lesion most commonly found on the lower lip and arises from minor salivary glands
It is a neoplastic lesion typically found on the tongue and requires chemotherapy
It is a retention cyst of major salivary glands and is commonly found over the parotid duct
Observation is sufficient in most cases as mucoceles tend to resolve spontaneously without intervention

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mucocele is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a bluish, soft cystic lesion most commonly found on the lower lip and arises from minor salivary glands

 

This option accurately summarizes the most common site (lower lip), lesion characteristics (soft, bluish), and origin (minor salivary glands).

 

A mucocele is a retention cyst that forms due to blockage or rupture of the duct of a minor salivary gland, resulting in mucus extravasation and a cyst-like swelling. Key clinical features include:

 

  • Most common site: Lower lip
  • Appearance: Soft, bluish, cystic swelling
  • Etiology: Often caused by trauma (e.g., lip biting)
  • Treatment: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice to prevent recurrence

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. It is a neoplastic lesion typically found on the tongue and requires chemotherapy: Incorrect. Mucoceles are not neoplastic and do not occur on the tongue; chemotherapy is not indicated.

 

Option C. It is a retention cyst of major salivary glands and is commonly found over the parotid duct: Incorrect. Mucoceles arise from minor, not major salivary glands; the parotid duct is unrelated to mucocele formation.

 

Option D. Observation is sufficient in most cases as mucoceles tend to resolve spontaneously without intervention: Incorrect. While some small mucoceles may temporarily regress, most require surgical excision to prevent recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucocele is a bluish, soft cystic lesion of minor salivary glands, most commonly on the lower lip, and requires surgical excision.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 223

choices.text: It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus and primarily affects adults
Lesions are large ulcers on the buccal mucosa that last more than 2 weeks
Vesicles appear on faucial pillars, tonsils, soft palate, and uvula and rupture into small ulcers
The ulcers are painless and typically exceed 1 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding herpangina is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vesicles appear on faucial pillars, tonsils, soft palate, and uvula and rupture into small ulcers

 

Herpangina is an acute viral illness most commonly seen in children, caused by Coxsackie A virus. It is characterized by:

 

  • Multiple small vesicles (initial lesions) that rupture to form ulcers
  • Ulcer size: 2–4 mm, not exceeding 1 cm
  • Sites involved: Faucial pillars, tonsils, soft palate, and uvula
  • Appearance: Ulcers have a yellow base with red areola
  • Duration: Self-limited, typically resolving within 1 week

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus and primarily affects adults: Incorrect. Herpangina is caused by Coxsackie virus, not Epstein-Barr virus, and typically affects children, not adults.

 

Option B. Lesions are large ulcers on the buccal mucosa that last more than 2 weeks: Incorrect. The ulcers are small (2–4 mm), not large, and they are not typically found on buccal mucosa; they last less than a week, not over 2 weeks.

 

Option D. The ulcers are painless and typically exceed 1 cm in size: Incorrect. The ulcers are painful and small (2–4 mm), not painless or >1 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpangina is a Coxsackie virus infection in children marked by small painful ulcers (2–4 mm) on faucial pillars, tonsils, soft palate, and uvula, usually resolving within a week.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 217

choices.text: Start high-dose systemic corticosteroids and wait 6 months before reassessment
Begin biweekly intralesional dexamethasone with hylase, stop irritants, and start jaw-opening exercises
Proceed directly with nasolabial flap surgery for immediate relief of trismus
Prescribe antifungal mouthwash and multivitamins only and observe

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a 10-year history of betel nut chewing presents with progressive difficulty opening his mouth, burning sensation while eating spicy food, and poor oral hygiene. Examination reveals palpable fibrotic bands in the buccal mucosa and trismus. He is diagnosed with advanced oral submucous fibrosis (OSF). Conservative management has failed, and surgical intervention is planned. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management before considering surgical treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Begin biweekly intralesional dexamethasone with hylase, stop irritants, and start jaw-opening exercises

 

Best reflects the standard initial medical treatment for OSF before surgical options are considered.

 

The first-line treatment for oral submucous fibrosis, especially in the early to moderate stages, includes medical management before considering surgery:

 

  • Intralesional steroid injections (Dexamethasone 4 mg + Hylase 1500 IU):
    • Delivered biweekly for 8–10 weeks
    • Reduces inflammation and collagen deposition
    • Improves mouth opening and burning sensation
  • Avoid irritants: Areca nut, tobacco, pan masala, spicy foods
  • Correct nutritional deficiencies: Vitamins, iron
  • Jaw-opening exercises: Help reduce fibrosis-related trismus

 

Surgical treatment is reserved for advanced cases where fibrosis causes severe trismus or failure of medical therapy. Surgical options include:

 

  • Buccal mucosal release with grafts or flaps (nasolabial, tongue, palatal, radial forearm)
  • Coronoidectomy and myotomy in severe cases

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Start high-dose systemic corticosteroids and wait 6 months before reassessment: Incorrect. Systemic steroids are less effective and have more side effects than intralesional steroids, especially without local delivery.

 

Option C. Proceed directly with nasolabial flap surgery for immediate relief of trismus: Incorrect. Surgery like nasolabial flap is for advanced unresponsive cases and carries complications like scarring and staged procedures.

 

Option D. Prescribe antifungal mouthwash and multivitamins only and observe: Incorrect. While vitamins help, antifungals are not indicated unless candida is proven. Observation alone is insufficient in a symptomatic, fibrotic case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of OSF involves intralesional steroids with hylase, cessation of irritants, nutritional support, and jaw exercises; surgery is reserved for advanced, refractory cases.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 221–222

choices.text: Recurrent lesions in adults commonly involve the buccal mucosa and soft palate
The causative organism is herpes simplex virus and secondary lesions often appear on vermilion border
Primary infection is milder than secondary infection due to prior immunity
Acyclovir is not effective and management is purely supportive

questions.text: Which of the following statements about herpetic gingivostomatitis is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The causative organism is herpes simplex virus and secondary lesions often appear on vermilion border

 

Herpetic gingivostomatitis, also called orolabial herpes, is caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) and occurs in two clinical forms:

 

  • Primary infection:
    • Seen in children, involves multiple vesicles that rupture into ulcers
    • Affects any part of the oral cavity
    • Accompanied by fever, malaise, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy
  • Secondary (recurrent) herpes:
    • Seen in adults, milder due to existing immunity
    • Affects the vermilion border (herpes labialis) most commonly
    • Less frequently, lesions may appear on the hard palate and gingiva
    • Triggered by stress, fatigue, fever, pregnancy, or immunodeficiency
    • Acyclovir 200 mg five times a day for 5 days shortens symptom duration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent lesions in adults commonly involve the buccal mucosa and soft palate: Incorrect. Recurrent herpes typically affects vermilion border, hard palate, and gingiva, not buccal mucosa or soft palate.

 

Option C. Primary infection is milder than secondary infection due to prior immunity: Incorrect. Primary infection is more severe. Secondary infection is milder due to partial immunity.

 

Option D. Acyclovir is not effective and management is purely supportive: Incorrect. Acyclovir is effective, especially in recurrent herpes labialis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpetic gingivostomatitis is caused by herpes simplex virus; secondary lesions commonly affect the vermilion border and respond to acyclovir.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 217

choices.text: The lesion is most likely leukoplakia, a clinical diagnosis of exclusion, with potential for malignant transformation
The lesion is most consistent with candidiasis and will resolve with antifungal treatment
Homogenous leukoplakia carries the highest risk of malignant change and must be excised immediately
Leukoplakia is usually diagnosed only after histopathological confirmation of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old male smoker presents for a routine dental check-up. On examination, a well-demarcated, painless white patch is noted on the buccal mucosa. The lesion is non-scrapable and has a slightly wrinkled appearance. The patient reports no associated pain or systemic symptoms. He also consumes alcohol regularly. The dentist suspects a premalignant lesion and refers him for further evaluation. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The lesion is most likely leukoplakia, a clinical diagnosis of exclusion, with potential for malignant transformation

 

Fits the clinical picture: non-scrapable white patch, smoker, alcohol user, buccal mucosa — meets definition of leukoplakia, a clinical diagnosis with premalignant potential

 

 

Leukoplakia is defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as a white patch of the oral mucosa that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. It is a clinical diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other white lesions such as lichen planus, candidiasis, lupus erythematosus, and white sponge nevus must first be ruled out.

 

Key facts:

 

  • Common in males in their 40s, especially those who smoke or chew tobacco
  • Most commonly affects the buccal mucosa, oral commissures, tongue, and floor of mouth
  • Clinical types:
    • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch; lower malignant potential
    • Nodular/Speckled and Erosive (erythroleukoplakia): Higher risk of malignant transformation
  • Malignant potential: Ranges from 1–17.5%, average ~5%
  • Management:
    • Remove causative factors
    • Biopsy suspicious lesions
    • Excision, laser, or cryotherapy for high-risk or persistent lesions

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The lesion is most consistent with candidiasis and will resolve with antifungal treatment. Incorrect: Candidiasis usually presents as scrapable white patches, often with erythema underneath, and responds to antifungals

 

Option C. Homogenous leukoplakia carries the highest risk of malignant change and must be excised immediately. Incorrect: Homogenous leukoplakia has the lowest risk of malignancy; it doesn’t always require excision unless histology shows dysplasia

 

Option D. Leukoplakia is usually diagnosed only after histopathological confirmation of squamous cell carcinoma. Incorrect: Leukoplakia is diagnosed clinically; biopsy is used to rule out dysplasia or malignancy, not to diagnose leukoplakia itself

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia is a clinical diagnosis of exclusion defined as a white patch that cannot be attributed to other diseases and carries a variable risk of malignant transformation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 224–225

choices.text: It is a painful ulcer seen at the tip of the tongue associated with nutritional deficiency
It is a congenital lesion arising due to failure of foramen cecum to close
It presents as a white patch on the ventral surface of the tongue with malignant potential
It is a red rhomboid area on the dorsum of the tongue in front of foramen cecum and may be associated with chronic candidiasis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding median rhomboid glossitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a red rhomboid area on the dorsum of the tongue in front of foramen cecum and may be associated with chronic candidiasis

 

Median rhomboid glossitis is a condition characterized by:

 

  • A red, rhomboid-shaped, depapillated patch on the dorsum of the tongue, just anterior to the foramen caecum
  • It was traditionally considered a developmental anomaly due to persistence of the tuberculum impar, which fails to invaginate properly during tongue formation
  • Recent evidence suggests an association with chronic Candida albicans infection
  • The lesion is typically asymptomatic and does not require treatment

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is a painful ulcer seen at the tip of the tongue associated with nutritional deficiency: Incorrect. The lesion is not painful and is not an ulcer; it's not associated with nutritional deficiency.

 

Option B. It is a congenital lesion arising due to failure of foramen cecum to close: Incorrect. It is not due to failure of foramen caecum to close but due to persistence of tuberculum impar.

 

Option C. It presents as a white patch on the ventral surface of the tongue with malignant potential: Incorrect. The lesion is red, not white, and appears on the dorsum of the tongue, not the ventral surface; it does not have malignant potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Median rhomboid glossitis appears as a red rhomboid depapillated area on the dorsal tongue anterior to foramen caecum, often linked to chronic candida infection.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 218

choices.text: Betel quid without tobacco is harmless and not associated with OSF
OSF has no correlation with socioeconomic status or nutritional deficiencies
OSF is a rare disease seen predominantly in Western countries
OSF is a chronic, insidious condition commonly seen in South Asia, linked to betel nut chewing and has a multifactorial etiology

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSF)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OSF is a chronic, insidious condition commonly seen in South Asia, linked to betel nut chewing and has a multifactorial etiology

 

Accurately summarizes OSF as a chronic, multifactorial condition common in South Asia, linked to betel nut chewing.

 

Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSF) is a precancerous condition affecting the oral cavity and pharynx, first described in India by Joshi in 1953. It is characterized by juxtaepithelial deposition of fibrous tissue leading to progressive stiffness of the oral mucosa and reduced mouth opening.

 

Key etiological factors include:

 

  • Betel-nut (areca nut) chewing: A major risk factor; often consumed alone or with tobacco, or as part of betel quid, which increases the risk of OSF more than leukoplakia or erythroplakia.
  • Tobacco and alcohol: Tobacco contributes to OSF and other precancerous lesions; alcohol increases the risk of OSF by 2-fold.
  • Poor socioeconomic status: Related to limited education, poor diet, and reduced access to healthcare.
  • Nutritional deficiencies: Particularly vitamin A, zinc, and antioxidants.
  • Immune mechanisms: Possible cell-mediated immune reaction to arecoline, suggesting an autoimmune or collagen disorder.
  • Multifactorial origin: Combined effects of betel nut, smoking, alcohol, and dietary deficiencies.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Betel quid without tobacco is harmless and not associated with OSF: Incorrect. Betel quid without tobacco still increases the risk of OSF and is classified as carcinogenic to humans.

 

Option B. OSF has no correlation with socioeconomic status or nutritional deficiencies:  Incorrect. Poor socioeconomic status and nutritional deficiencies are well-established contributing factors.

 

Option C. OSF is a rare disease seen predominantly in Western countries: Incorrect. OSF is common in South Asian countries (India, Pakistan, Nepal, Sri Lanka, etc.), not Western countries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral Submucous Fibrosis is a chronic, precancerous condition common in South Asia with multifactorial etiology including areca nut chewing, tobacco, alcohol, nutritional deficiencies, and immune mechanisms.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 219

choices.text: It is a bacterial infection affecting mainly adolescents
Oral lesions are seen on palate, tongue, and buccal mucosa along with vesicles on hands and feet
It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus and typically affects the palms only
Skin lesions are confined to the trunk and are scaly and pruritic

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease (HFMD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral lesions are seen on palate, tongue, and buccal mucosa along with vesicles on hands and feet

 

Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is a viral illness predominantly affecting children, caused most commonly by Coxsackievirus A16 or Enterovirus 71. It has the following key features:

 

  • Oral lesions: Vesicles and ulcers commonly found on the palate, tongue, and buccal mucosa
  • Skin lesions: Vesicles on the hands, feet, and sometimes the buttocks
  • It is a self-limiting disease and typically resolves within a week
  • Transmission occurs via fecal-oral and respiratory routes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a bacterial infection affecting mainly adolescents: Incorrect. HFMD is a viral, not bacterial infection, and it affects young children, not adolescents.

 

Option C. It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus and typically affects the palms only: Incorrect. HFMD is not caused by Epstein-Barr virus, and it does not limit to palms; it includes hands, feet, and buttocks.

 

Option D. Skin lesions are confined to the trunk and are scaly and pruritic: Incorrect. HFMD does not involve scaly or pruritic trunk lesions; lesions are vesicular, involving extremities and oral mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease is a viral illness in children characterized by oral lesions on palate, tongue, and buccal mucosa, along with vesicular eruptions on hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 217

choices.text: Submandibular gland is involved in approximately 90% of cases
Majority of salivary stones are radiolucent and cannot be detected on plain X-ray
All salivary stones require surgical excision of the entire gland regardless of location
Parotid gland is the most commonly involved site for stone formation

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent swelling and pain in the left submandibular region, especially during meals. On examination, the gland is mildly tender, and a hard mass is palpated along the duct. A plain X-ray reveals a radio-opaque shadow in the floor of the mouth. He is diagnosed with sialolithiasis. Which of the following statements about salivary calculi is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Submandibular gland is involved in approximately 90% of cases

 

Submandibular gland involvement in ~90% of sialolithiasis cases is well-documented.

 

Salivary calculi (sialolithiasis) are most commonly seen in the submandibular gland (90%) and less commonly in the parotid gland (10%). They form due to deposition of calcium phosphate over mucin or cellular debris.

 

Key points:

 

  • Stones may form in the duct or parenchyma
  • Submandibular gland is predisposed due to:
    • Longer duct (Wharton's duct)
    • Alkaline and mucous-rich saliva
    • Upward course of the duct
  • Symptoms: Intermittent pain and swelling, especially during meals
  • 80% of stones are radio-opaque (visible on X-ray)
  • Sialography is used for radiolucent stones
  • Management:
    • Peripheral duct stones: Removed intraorally
    • Hilar or intraparenchymal stones: May require gland excision

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Majority of salivary stones are radiolucent and cannot be detected on plain X-ray: Incorrect. 80% of stones are radio-opaque, not radiolucent; they are usually visible on X-rays.

 

Option C. All salivary stones require surgical excision of the entire gland regardless of location: Incorrect. Only deep or intraparenchymal stones require gland excision. Peripheral stones are managed intraorally.

 

Option D. Parotid gland is the most commonly involved site for stone formation: Incorrect. Parotid gland is involved in only ~10% of cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salivary calculi most commonly affect the submandibular gland, are usually radio-opaque, and treatment depends on stone location.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 231.

choices.text: Thrush presents as white patches that cannot be wiped off and is commonly seen in immunocompetent adults
Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is most commonly seen in infants and resolves spontaneously
Thrush and hypertrophic candidiasis presents as non-wipeable white lesions
Thrush is treated with topical nystatin or clotrimazole, while hypertrophic candidiasis may require excisional surgery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding oral candidiasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrush is treated with topical nystatin or clotrimazole, while hypertrophic candidiasis may require excisional surgery

 

Oral candidiasis (Moniliasis), caused by Candida albicans, occurs in two main forms:

 

1. Thrush:

 

  • Seen in infants, children, or immunocompromised adults (e.g., diabetes, malignancy, antibiotics, steroids, radiation)
  • Appears as white/grey patches over the oral mucosa and tongue
  • Patches can be wiped off, revealing red mucosa underneath
  • Treated with topical antifungals like nystatin or clotrimazole

 

 

2. Chronic Hypertrophic Candidiasis (Candidal Leukoplakia):

 

  • Seen mostly in adults
  • Appears as white plaques that cannot be wiped off
  • Commonly affects anterior buccal mucosa near the angle of the mouth
  • Often requires excisional surgery for treatment.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Thrush presents as white patches that cannot be wiped off and is commonly seen in immunocompetent adults: Incorrect. Thrush is wipeable and usually affects infants and immunocompromised adults, not immunocompetent ones.

 

Option B. Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is most commonly seen in infants and resolves spontaneously: Incorrect. Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is not common in infants and does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Option C. Thrush and hypertrophic candidiasis presents as non-wipeable white lesions: Incorrect. Thrush presents as wipeable white patches on the oral mucosa, while hypertrophic candidiasis presents as non-wipeable white lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrush responds to topical antifungals, while chronic hypertrophic candidiasis may need excisional surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 218

choices.text: OSF results from increased collagen synthesis and reduced collagen degradation driven by activated T-lymphocytes and macrophages
OSF is primarily mediated by B-cell proliferation and humoral immune response
Fibrosis in OSF is due to bacterial infection and release of elastases from neutrophils
The key feature of OSF is hypervascularity of lamina propria with abundant mast cells

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains the pathogenesis of Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSF)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OSF results from increased collagen synthesis and reduced collagen degradation driven by activated T-lymphocytes and macrophages

 

Precisely describes the immunological basis, emphasizing T-lymphocyte and macrophage involvement, leading to increased collagen production and reduced degradation.

 

Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSF) is a chronic premalignant condition characterized by fibroelastotic changes in the oral mucosa. The pathogenesis involves:

 

  • Areca nut chewing leads to chronic immune activation
  • Activated T-lymphocytes and macrophages accumulate in the subepithelial tissue
  • These immune cells secrete fibrogenic cytokines which:
    • Stimulate mesenchymal cells → ↑ fibroblast proliferation → ↑ collagen synthesis
    • Inhibit production of antifibrotic cytokines → ↓ collagenase → ↓ collagen degradation
  • This imbalance causes progressive fibrosis, loss of vascularity, and in late stages, trismus and tongue mobility restriction
  • There is a high CD4+/CD8+ T-cell ratio with minor B-cell involvement, confirming a cell-mediated (not humoral) immune mechanism
  • Histologically, plasma cells, lymphocytes, and fibrosis of the lamina propria are noted in advanced stages

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. OSF is primarily mediated by B-cell proliferation and humoral immune response: Incorrect. B-cells play a minor role; OSF is not primarily a humoral immune response.

 

Option C. Fibrosis in OSF is due to bacterial infection and release of elastases from neutrophils: Incorrect. OSF is not caused by infection or neutrophil elastase, but by chronic immune activation and fibrogenic cytokines.

 

Option D. The key feature of OSF is hypervascularity of lamina propria with abundant mast cells: Incorrect. Loss of vascularity, not hypervascularity, is a hallmark in advanced OSF; mast cells are not key players in this pathology.

 

Educational Objective:


OSF is caused by chronic immune-mediated activation of T-lymphocytes and macrophages, resulting in increased collagen production and reduced degradation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 219–220

choices.text: Sparing of hard palate and gingiva with absence of systemic symptoms
Presence of fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and involvement of gingiva
Involvement of non-movable mucosa with single large ulcer healing without scarring
Vesicular lesions on both skin and mucosa with accompanying malaise and myalgia

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with a 4-day history of painful oral ulcers. She has no fever, lymphadenopathy, or systemic symptoms. On examination, there are multiple 3–5 mm round ulcers with central yellowish necrotic areas and surrounding erythematous halos on the inner surface of her lips and buccal mucosa. The ulcers are tender to touch. She reports having similar episodes over the past few months, especially during periods of stress. She is otherwise healthy and not on any long-term medications. Which of the following features would best support the diagnosis of aphthous ulcers?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sparing of hard palate and gingiva with absence of systemic symptoms

 

This patient presents with classic minor aphthous ulcers:

 

  • Location: Affect movable oral mucosa – inner lips, buccal mucosa, soft palate, floor of mouth, and tongue
  • Appearance: Small (2–10 mm), round ulcers with necrotic center and red halo
  • No systemic signs: Aphthous ulcers are not associated with fever or lymphadenopathy
  • Recurrence: Episodes recur, often triggered by stress, nutritional deficiency, or hormonal changes

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Presence of fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and involvement of gingiva: Incorrect. Fever and lymphadenopathy are features of viral ulcers (e.g., primary herpetic gingivostomatitis), not aphthous ulcers.

 

Option C. Involvement of non-movable mucosa with single large ulcer healing without scarring: Incorrect. Non-movable mucosa and healing without scarring do not match major aphthous ulcers, which are 2–4 cm, affect similar sites but heal with scarring.

 

Option D. Vesicular lesions on both skin and mucosa with accompanying malaise and myalgia: Incorrect. Skin involvement, vesicles, and systemic symptoms suggest hand, foot and mouth disease or herpes simplex, not aphthous ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aphthous ulcers typically involve movable mucosa, spare the hard palate and gingiva, recur frequently, and are not associated with systemic symptoms.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 218

choices.text: Immediate frenotomy under local anesthesia
Reassure the parents that speech issues are unlikely due to tongue-tie if the tongue can protrude beyond lower incisors
Refer to speech therapy followed by surgical correction
Begin prophylactic antibiotics and schedule for surgical correction

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric ENT clinic by his parents who are concerned that he has difficulty pronouncing certain words. On examination, there is a short, thick lingual frenulum attaching the underside of the tongue to the floor of the mouth. However, the child is able to protrude his tongue beyond the lower incisors. There is no drooling, feeding difficulty, or dental hygiene issue noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure the parents that speech issues are unlikely due to tongue-tie if the tongue can protrude beyond lower incisors

 

The ability to protrude the tongue beyond the lower incisors is a reliable sign that speech issues are unlikely due to tongue-tie. Hence, reassurance is appropriate.

 

Ankyloglossia (tongue-tie) refers to a condition where the lingual frenulum is short or thick, limiting tongue movement. However, true tongue-tie that causes functional problems like speech impairment or poor oral hygiene is rare.

 

Key clinical points:

 

  • If the tongue can protrude beyond the lower incisors, it is unlikely to cause speech defects
  • A mobile tongue helps maintain oral hygiene, by preventing dental plaque and food debris accumulation
  • Treatment is indicated only when functional impairment is present, and includes transverse release and vertical closure, or simple incision for thin folds

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Immediate frenotomy under local anesthesia: Incorrect. Surgical release is not immediately necessary if there is no functional deficit, especially when tongue protrusion is adequate.

 

Option C. Refer to speech therapy followed by surgical correction: Incorrect. Speech therapy is not warranted at this stage as the tongue mobility is sufficient and there’s no confirmed speech defect due to tongue-tie.

 

Option D. Begin prophylactic antibiotics and schedule for surgical correction: Incorrect. There is no indication for antibiotics, and surgery is not needed without clinical symptoms or hygiene issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloglossia rarely causes speech issues if the tongue can protrude beyond the lower incisors; reassurance is appropriate in such cases.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 220

choices.text: Prescribe antifungal mouthwash and observe for 2 weeks
Perform excision biopsy due to high risk of malignant transformation
Reassure the patient, as red patches in the oral cavity are usually benign and self-limiting
Begin topical corticosteroid therapy for symptomatic relief

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for evaluation of a red patch on the inner aspect of his lower jaw that he noticed incidentally while brushing. He has a 30-year history of tobacco chewing. On examination, there is a velvety red, non-ulcerated patch over the gingivobuccal sulcus, not associated with pain or bleeding. A biopsy is planned. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform excision biopsy due to high risk of malignant transformation

 

Excision biopsy is the recommended management, both to diagnose and potentially treat erythroplakia due to its high rate of dysplasia or malignancy.

 

 

The red patch described is classic for erythroplakia, which is defined as a red plaque or patch on the mucosa that cannot be characterized as any other specific condition. Unlike leukoplakia (a white patch), erythroplakia has significantly higher malignant potential:

 

  • Appears red due to lack of keratinization, allowing underlying vascular connective tissue to be visible
  • Common sites: floor of mouth, gingivobuccal sulcus, lower alveolar mucosa
  • On histology, most erythroplakia cases show severe epithelial dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, or invasive carcinoma
  • Malignant transformation risk is 17 times higher than leukoplakia

 

Hence, excision biopsy is mandatory for diagnosis and treatment.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Prescribe antifungal mouthwash and observe for 2 weeks: Incorrect. Antifungal treatment is used for candidiasis, not erythroplakia. Observation is inappropriate due to the high malignant potential.

 

Option C. Reassure the patient, as red patches in the oral cavity are usually benign and self-limiting: Incorrect. Reassurance is not appropriate; erythroplakia is a high-risk premalignant lesion, not self-limiting.

 

Option D. Begin topical corticosteroid therapy for symptomatic relief: Incorrect. Corticosteroids are used in inflammatory oral conditions (like lichen planus), but not for erythroplakia, which is non-inflammatory and potentially malignant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythroplakia is a red mucosal patch with high malignant potential and requires prompt excision biopsy for diagnosis and management.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 225

choices.text: Observation, as pleomorphic adenomas rarely recur
Superficial parotidectomy with a margin of normal tissue
Incisional biopsy followed by simple enucleation of the mass
Chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy due to high risk of malignancy

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a painless, slowly enlarging mass in the region just below her right ear. She has no facial weakness or systemic symptoms. On examination, a firm, mobile mass is noted at the tail of the right parotid gland. Imaging confirms a well-defined lesion involving the superficial lobe of the parotid. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) suggests a benign mixed tumour. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy with a margin of normal tissue

 

Superficial parotidectomy is the standard treatment with adequate margins to reduce recurrence.

 

This patient presents with classical features of a pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumour, especially arising from the parotid gland. 

 

 

Key features include:

 

  • Slow-growing, painless, firm mass
  • Typically arises from the tail of the parotid
  • Common in females, in the 3rd or 4th decade
  • Histology shows both epithelial and mesenchymal elements, hence the term "mixed tumour"
  • Though encapsulated, it sends pseudopod extensions into surrounding tissue

 

Why superficial parotidectomy is needed:

 

  • If simply enucleated or shelled out, residual pseudopods can lead to recurrence
  • Hence, surgical excision should include normal surrounding gland tissue
  • In the parotid, this is achieved via superficial parotidectomy

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Observation, as pleomorphic adenomas rarely recur: Incorrect. Observation is not advised because incomplete excision leads to recurrence due to pseudopod infiltration.

 

Option C. Incisional biopsy followed by simple enucleation of the mass: Incorrect. Simple enucleation is not adequate due to risk of leaving behind pseudopods and recurrence.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy due to high risk of malignancy: Incorrect. Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign tumour; chemotherapy and radiotherapy are not indicated unless malignant transformation occurs, which is rare.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign, slow-growing mixed tumour of the salivary glands best treated by superficial parotidectomy with a margin of normal tissue to prevent recurrence.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 232–233.

choices.text: T2N2aM0 – Stage III
T4aN2aM0 – Stage IV A
T3N3M0 – Stage IV B
T4bN2cM1 – Stage IV C

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with a progressively enlarging, non-healing ulcer on the floor of the mouth. Examination reveals a 5 cm ulcerative lesion involving the floor of the mouth and extending into the underlying cortical bone. A firm, non-tender 4.5 cm lymph node is palpable in the ipsilateral level Ib region. Imaging confirms bony invasion and a single ipsilateral lymph node without distant metastasis. What is the TNM stage and overall stage of this patient’s oral cavity carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4aN2aM0 – Stage IV A

 

T4aN2aM0 – Stage IV A: Fits the clinical description perfectly.

 

From the TNM Classification (AJCC, 2002):

 

T-category (Tumor size and extent):

 

  • T4a (oral cavity): Tumor invades adjacent structures such as cortical bone, extrinsic muscles of the tongue, maxillary sinus, or skin.
    • This patient has cortical bone invasion, meeting criteria for T4a.

 

N-category (Nodal involvement):

 

  • N2a: A single ipsilateral lymph node >3 cm but ≤6 cm in diameter.
    • The patient has a 4.5 cm ipsilateral node, consistent with N2a.

 

M-category (Metastasis):

 

  • M0: No distant metastasis (as per case description)

 

Overall Stage (Table 44.3):

 

  • Stage IV A includes:
    • T4aN0M0
    • T4aN1M0
    • T4aN2M0
    • T1–T3 with N2 and M0

 

Thus, T4aN2aM0 corresponds to Stage IV A.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. T2N2aM0 – Stage III: T stage and stage. T2 is for tumors >2 cm and ≤4 cm, but here the lesion is 5 cm with bone invasion.

 

Option C. T3N3M0 – Stage IV B: N3 is for nodes >6 cm. This patient’s node is 4.5 cm, so N3 is incorrect.

 

Option D. T4bN2cM1 – Stage IV C: T4b implies invasion of deeper structures like masticator space or pterygoid plates; also, M1 (distant metastasis) is not present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion invading adjacent structures (e.g., cortical bone) with a 3–6 cm ipsilateral node and no distant metastasis is classified as T4aN2aM0, corresponding to Stage IV A oral cavity carcinoma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 226–227 (AJCC 2002 TNM Staging).

choices.text: Start oral antiviral therapy and monitor for spontaneous drainage
Initiate intravenous antibiotics, ensure hydration, and encourage salivary flow
Schedule immediate surgical drainage without attempting conservative management
Begin corticosteroids to reduce gland inflammation and suppress immune response

questions.text: An 82-year-old dehydrated woman with a history of recent prolonged hospitalization presents with fever, severe pain in the region near her left jaw, and difficulty moving her jaw. On examination, her left parotid gland is swollen, tender, and erythematous. Gentle pressure over the gland results in the expression of purulent discharge from the Stensen’s duct. Her WBC count is elevated with neutrophilic predominance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate intravenous antibiotics, ensure hydration, and encourage salivary flow

 

Intravenous antibiotics, hydration, and promotion of salivary flow are the first-line treatment.

 

This patient has acute suppurative parotitis, a bacterial infection of the parotid gland. It is most commonly seen in elderly, debilitated, and dehydrated patients and those with reduced salivary flow.

 

Key features of acute suppurative parotitis:

 

  • Sudden onset of severe pain in the parotid region
  • Fever, toxemia, and jaw movement pain
  • Purulent discharge from Stensen’s duct
  • Red and swollen duct opening
  • Most common causative organism: Staphylococcus aureus
  • Elevated WBC count with neutrophilia

 

Management:

 

  • Intravenous antibiotics targeting Gram-positive cocci and anaerobes
  • Hydration and measures to stimulate salivary flow (e.g., sialogogues)
  • Good oral hygiene
  • Surgical drainage only if medical therapy fails or abscess formation occurs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral antiviral therapy and monitor for spontaneous drainage: Incorrect. This is a bacterial, not viral, infection. Antivirals are inappropriate.

 

Option C. Schedule immediate surgical drainage without attempting conservative management: Incorrect. Surgical drainage is reserved for cases not responding to medical therapy or with abscess formation.

 

Option D. Begin corticosteroids to reduce gland inflammation and suppress immune response: Incorrect. Corticosteroids are not indicated and may worsen infection by suppressing immune response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute suppurative parotitis is managed with IV antibiotics, hydration, oral hygiene, and salivary stimulation; surgery is reserved for refractory cases.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 232

choices.text: Pleomorphic adenoma
Warthin tumor (Adenolymphoma)
Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
Oncocytoma

questions.text: A 62-year-old male smoker presents with a painless, slowly enlarging mass below his right ear for the past few months. Examination reveals a smooth, well-defined, non-tender mass in the tail of the parotid gland. Imaging shows a cystic lesion. FNAC reveals a benign neoplasm with both epithelial and lymphoid components. The lesion is suspected to contain brownish fluid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Warthin tumor (Adenolymphoma)

 

Fits the age, gender, tail of parotid involvement, cystic nature, and histologic description.

 

Warthin tumor (also called adenolymphoma or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) is a benign salivary gland tumour, most commonly arising from the tail of the parotid gland. 

 

 

Key features include:

 

  • Seen in older adults (5th–7th decade), with a strong male predominance (~5:1)
  • Often associated with smoking
  • Can be bilateral in 10% of cases and may be multiple
  • Cystic lesion that may contain mucoid or brownish fluid
  • Histology shows epithelial and lymphoid components
  • Though superficial parotidectomy is standard, it can be enucleated due to low recurrence risk

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pleomorphic adenoma: Also affects parotid but has a mixed epithelial-mesenchymal stroma and is more common in women and younger adults.

 

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Malignant tumour; presents with pain, rapid growth, or facial nerve involvement—none of which are present here.

 

Option D. Oncocytoma: Rare benign tumour composed of oncocytic cells, but lacks the lymphoid component and is usually solid, not cystic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warthin tumor (adenolymphoma) is a benign, cystic tumour of the parotid gland, typically seen in older males, containing epithelial and lymphoid tissue, and can be treated with enucleation or superficial parotidectomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 234

choices.text: Observation only, as low-grade parotid tumors in children rarely recur
Superficial parotidectomy with facial nerve preservation
Chemoradiation without surgery due to young age
Radical parotidectomy with facial nerve sacrifice and neck dissection

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a painless, slow-growing mass in the region of the left parotid gland. Imaging shows a well-defined lesion within the superficial lobe. FNAC reveals both mucin-producing and squamous epithelial cells. The lesion is diagnosed as a low-grade mucoepidermoid tumour. There is no facial nerve involvement on exam. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy with facial nerve preservation

 

Superficial parotidectomy is standard treatment for low-grade parotid tumors, and facial nerve is preserved if uninvolved.

 

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant salivary gland tumour, though low-grade variants can behave in a benign manner, especially in the parotid gland. However, due to its potential for recurrence and metastasis, it is still managed surgically.

 

 

Key points:

 

  • Contains mucin-producing and epidermoid (squamous) cells
  • More mucinous = less aggressive, more epidermoid = more aggressive
  • Low-grade tumors:
    • Common in children
    • Good prognosis (~90% 5-year survival)
    • Treated with superficial or total parotidectomy based on location
    • Facial nerve is preserved
  • High-grade tumors:
    • Aggressive, can invade facial nerve
    • Often require total parotidectomy, may need facial nerve sacrifice, and radical neck dissection due to risk of microscopic spread
  • Tumours in minor salivary glands behave more aggressively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation only, as low-grade parotid tumors in children rarely recur: Incorrect. Observation is not appropriate even for low-grade tumors due to risk of recurrence/metastasis.

 

Option C. Chemoradiation without surgery due to young age: Incorrect. Chemoradiation is not first-line treatment, especially in low-grade tumours and in children.

 

Option D. Radical parotidectomy with facial nerve sacrifice and neck dissection: Incorrect. Radical surgery and nerve sacrifice are reserved for high-grade, invasive tumours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the parotid gland is treated with superficial parotidectomy with preservation of the facial nerve.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 235

choices.text: Superficial parotidectomy with facial nerve preservation and no further treatment
Chemoradiation alone, as surgery is not effective in perineural tumors
Radical parotidectomy with wide margins and postoperative radiotherapy if margins are positive
Total parotidectomy with elective neck dissection in all patients, regardless of nodal status

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradually enlarging, painless mass in the region of the left parotid gland. She reports recent onset of left-sided facial weakness and constant dull pain radiating to her ear. On examination, there is a firm, fixed mass involving the deep lobe of the parotid, with House-Brackmann grade III facial nerve palsy. Imaging shows perineural spread of the tumor. Biopsy reveals a diagnosis of adenoid cystic carcinoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical parotidectomy with wide margins and postoperative radiotherapy if margins are positive

 

Radical parotidectomy with wide margins is essential. Post-op RT is given if margins are involved.

 

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (cylindroma) is a malignant salivary gland tumor that, although slow-growing, is locally aggressive, with a high risk of perineural invasion, recurrence, and distant metastasis (lungs, bone, brain). It often causes pain and facial nerve paralysis due to perineural spread.

 

Key clinical features:

 

  • Pain and VII nerve palsy due to perineural invasion
  • Tendency for late recurrences (even after 10–20 years)
  • Distant metastases can occur even with good local control
  • Lymphatic spread is less common, so radical neck dissection is not routine unless nodes are involved

 

Management:

 

  • Radical parotidectomy with the widest possible margin of normal tissue
  • Postoperative radiotherapy if margins are not free of tumor
  • Neck dissection only if lymph node metastasis is clinically or radiologically evident

 

 

On high power, cribriform glandular elements composed of a bland population of basaloid cells with a “Swiss-cheese” or sieve-like pattern are seen.

 

 

Tumor infiltrating beyond the capsule into the fat.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Superficial parotidectomy with facial nerve preservation and no further treatment: Incorrect. Superficial parotidectomy is inadequate; facial nerve is often already involved, and wide excision is needed

 

Option B. Chemoradiation alone, as surgery is not effective in perineural tumors: Incorrect. Chemoradiation alone is not the primary treatment; surgical excision remains the mainstay

 

Option D. Total parotidectomy with elective neck dissection in all patients, regardless of nodal status: Incorrect. Elective neck dissection is not routinely indicated in adenoid cystic carcinoma unless nodes are involved

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid cystic carcinoma of the salivary glands is treated with radical parotidectomy with wide margins and postoperative radiotherapy if surgical margins are not clear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 234–235.
